Sultan knows only that:

Some kind of crusade is being prepared (papal bull was public)

Assembly locations

Timeline for campaign launch

Existence of two separate armies

Naval component

Artillery presence

Specific strategic objectives

Crusade definitely launching spring 1431

Juan personally leading with papal backing

Mobilization in both Jaén region and Andalusia

Force size roughly 15,000-20,000 total (underestimate)

He does NOT know:

True scale (35,000 troops across both armies)

Two-army coordination and staggered deployment

Naval invasion plan

Artillery (5 bombards)

Specific targets beyond "frontier fortresses"

Timing of western naval assault relative to eastern advance

Granada's Response: Concentrates moderate forces (12,000-14,000) near Granada city and central frontier. Maintains strong western coastal garrisons. Moderate alert level. Some reinforcement of key frontier castles.

Sultan knows:

Major crusade launching early April 1431

Large eastern army (~20,000) assembling at Jaén

Smaller western force (~8,000-10,000) at Seville

Juan leading eastern army personally with banner and relics

Artillery present (though may not know exact number)

Crusader force of several hundred elite troops

General objective: penetrate toward Granada heartland

He does NOT know:

True western force size (thinks 8-10K, actually 12K)

Naval component of western strategy

Two-army coordination system and relay network

Staggered deployment (western waits for eastern commitment signal)

3,000 cavalry raiders as mobile screening force

Specific siege targets and operational plans

Granada's Response: Major force (16,000-18,000) concentrated against eastern approach, since that's where banner and Juan are. Maintains strong western defenses (6,000-8,000). High alert. All frontier castles reinforced and supplied. Calls for additional North African reinforcements. Prepares for prolonged campaign.

51-70: SUBSTANTIAL INTELLIGENCE (Moderate Failure for Secrecy)

Sultan knows:

Two major armies: ~23,000 east (Jaén) and ~12,000 west (Seville)

Eastern army has banner, relics, Juan II personally commanding

Western army has naval support component

Artillery present (5 bombards with eastern force)

Campaign launching early April, 8-month duration planned

500+ crusaders including experienced commanders

3,000 cavalry organized for raiding operations

Four forward supply depots supporting eastern army

Military Orders fully committed (4,500 troops)

He does NOT know:

Staggered deployment strategy (western delays for eastern commitment)

Relay communication system between armies

Specific coordination plan forcing him to divide forces

Exact timing of western naval assault

Detailed siege plans and specific fortress targets

Full extent of supply preparations and quartermaster efficiency

Granada's Response: Faces the dilemma Juan intended. Knows both threats but unsure which is primary. Most likely concentrates majority (18,000-20,000) against eastern army since Juan, banner, and relics are there. Leaves (6,000-8,000) defending west/coast. Urgently requests maximum North African reinforcements. Prepares Granada city for potential siege. May attempt preemptive strikes against supply depots.

71-85: DETAILED INTELLIGENCE (Significant Failure for Secrecy)

Sultan knows everything from 51-70, PLUS:

Western army deliberately timed to launch AFTER eastern army commits

Relay system between armies for coordination

Strategic intent: force Granada into unsolvable dilemma

Western force will launch 3-5 days after eastern army fully deployed

Specific high-value targets (major fortresses, key coastal cities)

Infante Juan commanding in west, Infante Enrique in east

Master Pedro González commanding eastern army under Juan

Full supply chain details and depot locations

He does NOT know:

Exact day western fleet launches (within ~week window)

Detailed tactical plans for specific sieges

Internal command relationships and potential weaknesses

Some operational details and contingency plans

Granada's Response: Fully aware of the strategic trap. Must still choose where to commit primary forces. Likely keeps forces more balanced (13,000-15,000 east, 10,000-12,000 west) to avoid being overwhelmed on either front, but this means neither front is overwhelming. Maximum mobilization. Considers trying to defeat eastern army quickly before western lands. Prepares ambushes at mountain passes. Attempts to disrupt relay system.

Sultan knows virtually everything about the crusade plans except the most sensitive tactical details. Has detailed maps, force compositions, command structures, supply chains, timeline, coordination systems, and strategic objectives. Likely has spies in noble households or corrupted officials providing regular reports.

Granada's Response: Fully prepared for both-front war. May attempt innovative counters like preemptive naval raids against Seville fleet before it launches, ambushes against artillery columns, raids on supply depots, or trying to foment noble dissent in Castile. Still faces strategic dilemma but has maximum time to prepare response.

96-100: NEAR-PERFECT INTELLIGENCE (Catastrophic Failure for Secrecy)

Sultan has penetrated inner circle or corrupted high-level officials. Knows everything including most sensitive tactical details, contingency plans, internal disagreements, command relationships, and operational timetables down to specific dates. May even know about Isabel's pregnancy or other personal matters affecting command decisions.

Granada's Response: Can prepare optimal counterstrategy. Possible pre-emptive strikes before April launch. May try assassination attempts against key commanders. Prepares sophisticated deception operations. Could attempt diplomatic offensive to split Castilian nobles. Still must fight the war, but has every possible advantage intelligence can provide.

Strengths: Concentrates maximum force against main threat, uses terrain, potentially decisive battle
Weaknesses: Vulnerable if western army is larger than expected, risky if eastern army too strong, puts everything on one throw

Assessment: Bold strategy that could work if eastern army defeats decisively, but risky given unknown about western force.

6,000-8,000 raiders strike supply depots at Úbeda, Baeza, Ciudad Real

Attempt to damage ships, burn supplies, create chaos

After raids, fall back to prepared defensive positions

Strengths: Initiative, disrupts crusader preparations, psychological impact, forces crusaders to defend rear
Weaknesses: Raids might fail, provokes earlier response, could lose raiding forces, doesn't solve underlying numerical problem

Commit 16,000-18,000 troops to offensive through mountain passes

Catch crusaders unprepared, destroy forward elements

Seize or destroy supply depots

If successful, potentially forces crusade cancellation for year

Maintain defensive posture in west (6,000-8,000)

Naval forces protect western coast and supply lines

Strengths: Could catch crusaders unprepared, numerical advantage while enemy assembling, decisive early victory possible, enormous psychological impact
Weaknesses: Very risky leaving Granada defenseless, mountain offensive difficult, if fails leaves Granada vulnerable, crusaders could counter-attack weakened force

Assessment: High-risk, high-reward strategy. Success could destroy crusade; failure could doom Granada. Requires excellent timing and execution.

Strategy: All-out offensive on both fronts simultaneously

12,000 troops strike east toward Jaén (late March)

10,000 troops + naval assault west toward Seville (late March)

Goal: Preemptively shatter crusade before it launches

Catch both armies while still assembling

Seize initiative completely, force crusaders into defensive

Accept risk to Granada city (leave minimal garrison ~2,000)

Everything on offensive success

Strengths: Maximum initiative, could destroy crusade before it starts, catches enemy unprepared, shocking boldness
Weaknesses: Extremely risky, leaves Granada nearly defenseless, both offensives must succeed or Granada loses everything, difficult coordination, crusaders might defeat forces piecemeal

Assessment: Desperate gamble that could win war immediately or lose it catastrophically. Would be out of character for competent Sultan unless he has intelligence suggesting crusade is weaker than it appears.

Evacuate and burn all frontier settlements, farms, villages

Destroy everything of value crusaders could use (food, fodder, water sources)

Create wasteland between Castile and Granada heartland

22,000+ troops defending prepared positions

Send urgent appeals for more Muslim reinforcements (offer anything)

Accept massive civilian suffering to make conquest impossibly expensive

Strengths: Makes conquest economically and logistically impossible, removes all resources from crusaders, united defense, psychological warfare
Weaknesses: Destroys own frontier population's livelihoods, creates internal dissent, abandons everything except capital, horrific civilian suffering, if Granada falls anyway, nothing left

Assessment: Total war strategy born of desperation or absolute conviction. Would only make sense if Sultan believes crusade intends genocide rather than conquest.

The sun rose over a transformed landscape. Where weeks ago there had been open fields and scattered camps outside Jaén's walls, now stretched a city of canvas and steel—23,000 men assembled under the banner of the cross.

Juan stood atop the fortress walls at dawn, Isabel beside him, both watching the army wake. Cook fires kindled by the hundreds, creating a haze of smoke across the valley. The sounds carried up—officers shouting orders, horses neighing, the constant din of an army preparing for war.

"It's real now," Isabel murmured, her hand resting unconsciously on her belly. She'd been unusually tired these past few days, and her morning appetite had been... strange. But she said nothing of it yet.

Juan nodded. "God willing, by summer's end, Granada will kneel."

Below, the assembly was complete. The final noble contingents had arrived yesterday—the Count of Niebla with his 800 men, the Marquis of Santillana with 600 more. Pedro González's meticulous accounting confirmed it: 23,147 troops present and accounted for.

The Eastern Army - Final Composition:

2,000 Crown professional troops (veterans, well-equipped)

4,500 Military Order knights and men-at-arms (Calatrava 1,500, Santiago 2,000, Alcántara 1,000)

18,000 noble levies (quality varied, but all properly armed)

267 crusaders (from Toledo, arrived three days ago)

5 bombards with crews (Pietro Calabrese commanding)

Support personnel, surgeons, chaplains

The white banner with the True Cross and Santiago's bone hung from the fortress's highest tower, visible for miles. The Guardian Company—now 80 strong after recent additions—maintained constant vigil around it.

The Cavalry Muster

By mid-morning, Juan descended to the cavalry assembly ground southeast of the main camp. Three thousand horsemen waited—the finest light cavalry from across Castile, many from frontier families who'd spent lifetimes raiding and skirmishing with Moorish forces.

Pedro González stood at the center with six commanders arrayed before their columns. Each commander led 500 cavalry organized into five troops of 100. The horses stamped and snorted, eager after weeks of rest and grain.

The Six Column Commanders:

Column One - Don García Fernández de Baeza
Age 38, veteran of twenty frontier campaigns. Lean, scarred face, reputation for aggressive pursuit. Commands 500 horsemen from Jaén and Úbeda region. Knows the central approaches intimately.

Column Two - Don Rodrigo de Narváez
Age 42, from minor nobility of Antequera frontier. Spent entire adult life in border warfare. Cautious, methodical, never loses men unnecessarily. Commands 500 from Córdoba and Écija region.

Column Three - Don Pedro Manrique de Lara
Age 29, younger cousin of Rodrigo Manrique. Hungry to prove himself, excellent horseman. Commands 500 mixed cavalry including 100 Military Order knights from Santiago.

Column Four - Don Álvar Pérez de Guzmán
Age 35, from Seville's frontier nobility. Speaks Arabic fluently, understands Moorish tactics deeply. Commands 500 Andalusian cavalry, many with Moorish horses.

Column Five - Don Juan de Luna (no relation to Álvaro)
Age 33, from Murcia frontier. Specialized in deep reconnaissance, can survive weeks behind enemy lines. Commands 500 eastern frontier cavalry familiar with mountain passes.

Column Six - Don Sancho de Rojas
Age 40, veteran commander from Calatrava Order. Solid, reliable, coordinates well with others. Commands 500 mixed cavalry including 150 Military Order knights from Calatrava and Alcántara.

Juan's Orders

The king addressed them from horseback, his father's sword at his hip, wearing lighter armor suitable for a command role rather than combat. Around him stood Pedro González, Infante Enrique, and the senior commanders.

"Gentlemen, you are the eyes and shield of this army. Your mission is threefold:

First: Reconnaissance. I need to know what lies ahead. Every fortress, every pass, every water source between here and Granada. Where the Sultan's forces are positioned. Their strength, their movements, their intentions. The main army cannot advance blind.

Second: Screening. Deny the enemy intelligence about our movements and strength. Drive off their scouts. Intercept their messengers. Make them uncertain about where we are and what we intend.

Third: Disruption. Strike their supply lines, foraging parties, isolated detachments. Make them afraid to move in small groups. Force them to concentrate, which limits their flexibility.

You have complete freedom of movement. I do not dictate your routes or methods. You are professional raiders—use your judgment. But report back regularly. I need current intelligence every three days at minimum.

Rules of Engagement:

Avoid pitched battles against superior forces. You are scouts and raiders, not the main battle line.

Preserve your forces. Dead cavalry tell no tales and gather no intelligence.

Treat prisoners according to the customs of war. We want defectors and informants.

Civilian populations are to be left unmolested unless they actively resist. We are liberating these lands, not devastating them.

Any questions?"

Don Rodrigo de Narváez spoke: "Your Majesty, how deep do you want us ranging? There's a difference between screening the immediate frontier and raiding deep into Granada."

Juan glanced at Pedro González, who nodded. "Initially, stay within two days' ride of the main army. As we advance and secure fortresses, you'll range deeper. I want a flexible screen that moves with us, not raiders operating independently far from support."

Don García Fernández de Baeza: "And if we encounter the Sultan's cavalry forces? His Moroccan horsemen are excellent fighters."

"Avoid them unless you have clear advantage," Juan replied. "But if forced to fight, fight smart. Use terrain. Use ambush. Remember—you win by surviving and reporting what you learned, not by dying gloriously."

Infante Enrique added, "I've fought Moorish cavalry. They're fast and skilled, but they prefer open ground. Use forests, rough country, anything that limits their mobility. And watch for their feigned retreats—it's a favorite tactic."

The commanders nodded, appreciating the practical advice.

Deployment

The six columns departed over the next two hours, each taking different routes into the frontier:

Column One (García Fernández): Southeast toward Alcalá la Real, the nearest major Moorish fortress (20 miles distant). Mission: Reconnaissance of immediate approaches.

Column Two (Rodrigo de Narváez): South-southwest toward Moclín fortress (25 miles). Mission: Scout western approaches and potential flanking routes.

Column Three (Pedro Manrique): Due south toward Íllora (30 miles). Mission: Deep reconnaissance toward Granada's northern defenses.

Column Four (Álvar Pérez): Southeast toward Cambil fortress (25 miles). Mission: Scout eastern approaches and mountain passes.

Father Tommaso's accounting system proved its worth—every barrel of grain, every horseshoe, every bolt of canvas was tracked and positioned.

March 27, Evening - First Scout Returns

Don Sancho de Rojas, commanding the reserve cavalry, found Pedro González as dusk fell. "Master, rider from Don García's column just arrived. He requests audience with His Majesty."

The messenger was a young knight, his horse lathered from hard riding. Dust covered his face, and his armor showed signs of hasty travel through rough country.

Pedro summoned you to the command chamber where maps of the frontier were spread across tables. Infante Enrique was already present, having been reviewing defensive positions.

The young knight—Diego de Córdoba—stood at attention. Pedro nodded for him to report.

"Your Majesty, Commander Don García sends his compliments. My column reached the approaches to Alcalá la Real. The fortress is garrisoned—we estimate 800-1,000 men based on activity observed. They're alert but not expecting immediate attack. Their cavalry patrols extend perhaps five miles from the walls, but we evaded them easily."

Diego paused, catching his breath. "More importantly, Your Majesty—we encountered Moorish cavalry, approximately 300 riders, ranging northwest from the fortress. They're screening their own territory, looking for us just as we're looking for them. We shadowed them for half a day. They're good, well-mounted, disciplined. Moroccan professionals, we think, not local militia."

He gestured to the map. "Don García believes there are likely 2,000-3,000 cavalry total operating across the frontier in mobile columns, similar to our own deployment. They're not concentrated—they're spread out, probing and screening. He requests permission to continue reconnaissance deeper toward Alcalá la Real's southern approaches."

Pedro looked at the map thoughtfully. "Granada's using mobile cavalry just as we are. Smart."

Infante Enrique added, "Those Moroccan horsemen are dangerous. If our columns encounter them in equal numbers, it'll be a real fight."

The messenger continued, "One more thing, Your Majesty. We captured a local farmer near Alcalá who'd been pressed into service providing supplies to the fortress. He says the garrison has been reinforced in the last month—additional troops, supplies stockpiled for long siege. The Sultan's preparing for us."

March 28, Afternoon - More Reports

Over the next day, riders returned from three more columns:

From Don Rodrigo de Narváez (Column Two - Moclín):
"Moclín fortress strongly garrisoned, perhaps 700-800 men. Limited cavalry patrols. Fortress sits on high ground, approaches difficult. No signs of major field army in this sector. Local villages appear normal—no evacuation, no scorched earth. Requests permission to probe further west."

From Don Álvar Pérez de Guzmán (Column Four - Cambil):
"Cambil fortress garrisoned with 500-600 men. Observed Moorish cavalry patrol of approximately 200 riders. They spotted us and withdrew quickly—didn't seek engagement. Mountain passes south of Cambil appear lightly defended. Significant intelligence: spoke with a Mudéjar merchant (under safe conduct) who reports Sultan's main army—estimated 16,000-18,000 troops—positioned roughly 40 miles south, between Loja and Granada city itself. They're centrally positioned to respond to threats from any direction. Merchant seemed reliable—his information matches what we've observed."

From Don Pedro Manrique (Column Three - Íllora):
"Íllora fortress heavily garrisoned—at least 1,000 men. Strong defensive position. Encountered Moorish cavalry force of 400-500 riders. Brief skirmish—we withdrew after confirming their strength. Lost two men wounded, killed three of theirs. They didn't pursue aggressively. Believe this is part of larger screening force. Terrain south of Íllora is rough—advantage to defenders."

March 29, Morning - The Clearest Picture

Don Juan de Luna's column, which had ranged farthest east toward Guadix, returned with the most detailed intelligence.

The commander himself presented his report, spreading his own hand-drawn maps on the table. Luna was weathered, competent, and clearly exhausted from days of constant riding.

"Your Majesty, Master Pedro, my lords—here's what we found:

The eastern frontier is less heavily defended than the central approaches. Guadix has perhaps 600 troops. The mountain passes east of Granada are garrisoned but not heavily—they're betting we'll come through the center, not the flanks.

Most significantly: we ranging far enough south to observe the Sultan's main encampment. It's positioned here"—he pointed to a spot between Loja and Granada—"roughly equidistant from the central and western approaches. Best estimate: 17,000-18,000 troops. They have a substantial cavalry screen, perhaps 2,500-3,000 horsemen ranging across the entire frontier. Their camp is organized, well-supplied. They're not panicking—they're waiting to see where we commit.

The Sultan's playing it smart. He's positioned centrally so he can march to reinforce wherever we strike. If we besiege Alcalá la Real, he can reach it in two days. If we push toward Moclín, same thing. He's not committing until we do."

Pedro González studied the maps intently. "So he knows we're here. He knows we're strong. But he doesn't know our exact strength or our objective yet. He's waiting to see where we push, then he'll respond with his main army."

Luna nodded. "That's my assessment, Master. And there's one more thing—the fortresses are all supplied for extended sieges. Months, not weeks. They're dug in and waiting."

exchanges.text:
Time to make a choice. I summon my war council to decide what to do.


Crusaders, we are moving out. The question is, what is our target. We have scouted most border forts. Shall we go through the center, or take eastern approaches? If we go through the center and teh sultan responds, what will happen when he deploys his army against us?

Juan's questions are:
1. Central or eastern approaches?
2. If we go through center and Sultan deploys against us, what happens?

I should have these experienced commanders debate the options realistically, considering:
- Granada's mobile defense strategy
- The 23,000 vs 17-18,000 troop numbers
- Terrain advantages/disadvantages
- Siege warfare realities
- Supply lines
- The western army coordination

Let me draft realistic military debate from professionals.

War Council - March 29, Evening, Jaén

The command chamber filled with the army's leadership. Pedro González stood near the maps, Infante Enrique beside him. The six cavalry commanders arrayed themselves around the table—García Fernández, Rodrigo de Narváez, Álvar Pérez, Pedro Manrique, Juan de Luna, and Sancho de Rojas. Captain Fernán represented the crusaders. Pietro Calabrese stood somewhat apart, the Italian master gunner uncomfortable in councils of war. Fray Hernando observed from near the window, saying nothing yet.

Pedro González spoke first. "Your Majesty asks the essential question. The Sultan waits centrally. Wherever we strike, he can respond. So let's examine both options honestly."

Don García Fernández de Baeza (veteran frontier fighter, aggressive):

"The central approach is the most direct. Alcalá la Real is twenty miles from here. Take it, and we have a forward base. From there, it's perhaps another thirty miles to Loja, then thirty more to Granada itself. Straight shot, relatively speaking. The terrain is difficult but not impossible for an army our size."

He paused. "But Your Majesty asks what happens when the Sultan deploys against us. Here's the reality: if we besiege Alcalá la Real, he'll march his 18,000 troops north within days. We'll face them in the field while simultaneously conducting a siege. That means dividing our forces—part besieging the fortress, part facing his field army."

Don Rodrigo de Narváez (cautious, methodical):

"And that's dangerous, Your Majesty. Sieges consume men like a mill grinds grain. If we commit 8,000 troops to surround and assault Alcalá la Real, we have 15,000 to face the Sultan's field army. That's still advantage to us numerically, but not overwhelming. And we'd be fighting with a fortress at our backs and a hostile army in front—caught between hammer and anvil."

Infante Enrique (tactical experience):

"I've seen this before in Italian campaigns. The besieging force always suffers when a relief army arrives. You're static, committed to siege lines, supplies are dispersed. The relief force chooses when and where to strike. Even with superior numbers, the advantage shifts to the defender."

He gestured to the map. "If we push through the center and the Sultan responds with his main army, we'll get our decisive battle—but on terms that favor him somewhat. He'll force us to either lift the siege or fight divided."

Don Juan de Luna (deep reconnaissance specialist):

"The eastern approach offers different problems and opportunities. The mountain passes are lightly defended. Guadix has only 600 men—we could take it more easily than Alcalá. The terrain is harder, rougher, but that works both ways. It's harder for the Sultan to bring his entire army through those mountains quickly."

Don Pedro Manrique (younger, eager to prove himself):

"But the eastern route is slower, Your Majesty. Forty to fifty miles through mountains just to reach Guadix, then we'd still be nearly a hundred miles from Granada city. We'd spend weeks securing mountain fortresses before we even threaten the heartland. The Sultan would have time to reposition, fortify, prepare."

Pietro Calabrese (artillery master, speaking with heavy Italian accent):

"Your Majesty, I must speak of the bombards. Through mountains—very difficult. The roads, they are not good. Each gun needs eight oxen minimum, maybe ten for mountains. We go slow, maybe five miles per day through rough country. And if we must set up for siege in mountains... the positioning, very difficult. Mountains favor defender always."

He gestured emphatically. "Through center, roads better. I can move guns faster, position them properly. Against Alcalá la Real, I can place bombards on good ground, pound walls effectively. In mountains... " He shrugged expressively.

Don Álvar Pérez de Guzmán (Arabic speaker, understands Moorish tactics):

"The Sultan is executing classic mobile defense, Your Majesty. He waits for us to commit, then responds. Whichever route we choose, he'll march to meet us. The question isn't whether we'll face him—it's where and under what conditions."

He leaned over the map. "If we go through the center, we face him soon, probably within two weeks. Large battle, high stakes, fortress sieges with relief armies. If we go east, we avoid him initially, take weaker fortresses, but he has time to concentrate wherever we emerge from the mountains. Eventually, we still face him—just later and perhaps on ground more of his choosing."

Pedro González de Padilla (overall commander, thoughtful):

"Your Majesty, here's my assessment: We have 23,000 troops to their 17-18,000. That's significant advantage, but not crushing. If we meet them in open battle on reasonable ground, we should win. Our numbers, our equipment, our morale—all favor us.

But the danger is not the field battle itself. The danger is fighting that battle while simultaneously conducting siege operations. That divides our attention, our supplies, our command structure. We're doing two things at once while the Sultan does one thing with full focus.

The central route gives us the most direct path to Granada, but it guarantees early confrontation with their main army. The eastern route delays that confrontation but commits us to difficult mountain warfare where our numerical advantage matters less and our artillery is hampered."

He paused, measuring his words carefully. "There's a third consideration, Your Majesty. The western army. If we push through the center and draw the Sultan's full attention, that creates the perfect conditions for Rodrigo Manrique's naval assault. The Sultan commits everything to stopping us, his western coast becomes vulnerable."

Don Sancho de Rojas (Calatrava Order, solid veteran):

"But if we go east, Your Majesty, the Sultan might not commit fully. He might keep forces in reserve, maintain flexibility. That makes the western coordination less effective. The two-army strategy works best if we force him to make a hard choice—and the central thrust with the banner and yourself personally leading forces that choice most clearly."

Fray Hernando finally spoke from the window, his voice quiet but carrying:

"Your Majesty asked what happens if we go through the center and the Sultan deploys against us. You'll face the largest battle the frontier has seen in a generation. Many will die. The crusaders will be tested in blood. You'll carry the True Cross and Santiago's bones into combat against the armies of Islam—exactly as the Pope blessed you to do.

Is that not why we came? Not to spend months taking mountain fortresses, but to break Granada's power in decisive combat? The banner was not blessed for sieges. It was blessed for battle."

The chamber fell quiet. Every man present understood the weight of the choice.

Don García Fernández added one more thought: "Your Majesty, whatever we choose, we must choose soon. Every day we wait here, Granada solidifies defenses and our surprise diminishes. The cavalry screening is effective, but they know we're here. They know we're strong. Soon they'll know exactly how strong."

The commanders waited for your decision.

Have faith Don Garcia. We will move out. 
What is the training and equipment of the infantry of the Moors? I have heard a lot about their cavalry, but how is their infantry?

Don Rodrigo de Narváez (twenty years frontier experience) responded first:

"Their infantry is mixed quality, Your Majesty. The professional Granadan troops—perhaps 8,000 of them—are well-trained, well-equipped. They wear mail or scale armor, carry good steel weapons, fight in disciplined formations. Many use crossbows effectively. These men are dangerous—veterans who've held the frontier for years. They'll stand and fight."

Don Álvar Pérez de Guzmán (who speaks Arabic and knows Moorish tactics intimately) elaborated:

"The Moroccan reinforcements—those 5,000 troops—are also professionals, Your Majesty. North African infantry, many of them. They favor spears and shields, fight in tight formations, very disciplined. They're religiously motivated, fighting for jihad. They won't break easily.

But the militia—those 8,000 or so—are another matter entirely. Farmers and townsmen pressed into service. Leather armor at best, often just padded cloth. Spears, maybe swords, poor shields. Minimal training. They'll man walls adequately during sieges, but in open battle?" He shook his head. "They'll fold if pressed hard. The Sultan knows this—he'll use them for garrison duty and keep his professionals for field combat."

Infante Enrique added his perspective:

"I've fought Moorish infantry at Antequera years ago. Their professionals are competent but not exceptional. They lack the heavy infantry tradition—no true pike formations, no deep ranks of armored footmen like we field. They rely heavily on missile troops—crossbows, javelins, some archery. In close combat, man-to-man, our heavy infantry has the advantage."

Don Juan de Luna provided specific tactical assessment:

"Their infantry doctrine emphasizes defensive fighting, Your Majesty. They're excellent at holding fortifications—disciplined, patient, good at using walls and terrain. But in open field battle, they're vulnerable. They lack the weight and momentum of Castilian heavy infantry. Our men-at-arms, properly led, will push through their lines.

The danger is their combined arms. They use infantry and cavalry together effectively—infantry holds position while cavalry strikes flanks and rear. That's where they're most dangerous. But pure infantry against infantry? We have the advantage in equipment, training, and fighting style."

Don García Fernández concluded bluntly:

"Your Majesty, if we meet their field army in open battle, their cavalry is the real threat—those Moroccan horsemen especially. Their infantry will fight, the professionals will die hard, but they can't stop 23,000 Castilian troops if we commit properly. The battle will be won or lost based on cavalry actions and whether we can maintain formation under their mobile attacks."

Pedro González summarized:

"In short, Your Majesty: their infantry is adequate for defense, dangerous behind walls, but inferior to ours in open battle. Which means if we force a field engagement through the central approach, we should prevail—assuming we don't let their cavalry disrupt our formations or catch us divided during siege operations."

The commanders waited to see how this information affected your strategic thinking.
So we lay siege to a fort, divide our forces, let them come to us. Does forcing them to attack us favor us? They excel in fighting style like you just indicated.

Juan is asking a smart tactical question - if the Moors excel at mobile warfare with combined infantry/cavalry tactics, and if besieging a fortress forces the crusaders to divide their forces, does forcing the Sultan to attack the crusader army while it's besieging actually favor the crusaders? Or does it play into Moorish strengths?

This is exactly the kind of strategic dilemma that should be debated. Let me have the commanders respond thoughtfully to this question.

Pedro González paused, clearly impressed by the question. He exchanged glances with several of the veteran commanders.

"Your Majesty cuts to the heart of the matter. You're right to question this."

Don Rodrigo de Narváez (the cautious, methodical one) spoke carefully:

"If we besiege a fortress and the Sultan marches to relieve it, yes—we force him to come to us. But Your Majesty is correct to ask whether that actually favors us. Let me be honest: a relieving army attacking prepared positions usually has the advantage of choosing when and where to strike. We're static, committed to siege lines. He can probe, maneuver, strike at weak points."

Infante Enrique nodded grimly:

"And their cavalry excels at exactly that kind of warfare—mobile strikes, flanking attacks, disrupting supply lines while avoiding direct engagement. If we're spread around a fortress conducting a siege, we're vulnerable to being struck piecemeal. They could raid our supply trains, hit isolated detachments, force us to either abandon the siege or fight at disadvantage."

Don Álvar Pérez de Guzmán elaborated on Moorish tactical doctrine:

"Your Majesty understands correctly. The Moors don't want to smash themselves against prepared heavy infantry. They want mobility, flexibility—cavalry sweeping around flanks while infantry holds key positions. If we're locked into siege lines, we've surrendered mobility. That plays to their strengths, not ours."

Don García Fernández (the aggressive one) interjected:

"But there's another side to this, Your Majesty. If the Sultan comes to relieve a fortress, he must engage us eventually. He can't just dance around forever—the fortress garrison needs relief, needs supplies, needs rescue. At some point he has to commit to battle. And when he does commit, our superior numbers and heavy infantry should prevail."

Don Juan de Luna shook his head:

"Only if we can force him into the kind of battle that favors us, García. But if we're divided between siege operations and facing his field army, he chooses the terms. He might strike our siege lines when we're unprepared. He might ignore the fortress entirely and march past us to raid deeper into our supply lines. He might engage just enough to disrupt the siege, then withdraw before we can bring our full strength to bear."

Don Sancho de Rojas (Calatrava veteran) added a historical perspective:

"I've seen this before, Your Majesty. At Antequera in '410, we besieged the fortress with 12,000 men. The Moors brought a relief army. For weeks they harassed us—raids, skirmishes, cutting supply lines. Never gave us the decisive battle we wanted. Eventually we took the fortress, but it cost us months and hundreds of men to harassment."

Pedro González synthesized the discussion:

"Your Majesty, the honest answer is this: forcing them to attack us while we besiege sounds advantageous in theory—we're prepared, they must come to us. But in practice, their tactical flexibility and cavalry superiority means they can choose how to attack, when to attack, and whether to fully commit. We end up reactive, responding to their moves while also conducting a siege.

The real question is whether we want a siege-with-relief-battle scenario at all, or whether we want to force a decisive field engagement on more open terms."

Don Álvar Pérez posed the alternative:

"What if we don't besiege immediately, Your Majesty? What if we advance toward a fortress—say Alcalá la Real—make clear we intend to take it, but don't commit to full siege lines? Keep the army concentrated and mobile. Force the Sultan to either defend the fortress with his field army or abandon it. That way we're not divided, we maintain flexibility, and if battle comes, it's on more equal terms."

Infante Enrique considered this:

"A demonstration in force rather than immediate siege. Show we can take the fortress, force him to respond, but don't lock ourselves into static positions until we've dealt with his field army. That changes the dynamic considerably."

Don Rodrigo de Narváez warned:

"But that requires patience and discipline, Your Majesty. The nobles will want to storm fortresses, take prizes, show results. Maneuvering without immediate siege might frustrate them. And the longer we maneuver without taking fortresses, the more time Granada has to prepare and reinforce."

Pietro Calabrese the artillery master spoke up:

"Your Majesty, if you do not besiege immediately, my bombards—what do they do? We march them close to fortress, set them up, pound walls... this takes days. If we then march away without siege, we waste time and effort. The guns, they want to shoot, not march back and forth."

The commanders looked at each other, then back to you. The strategic dilemma was clear:

Full siege divides forces and plays to Moorish tactical strengths

Demonstration without siege maintains flexibility but sacrifices immediate gains

The Sultan's mobile defense strategy is designed precisely to create this dilemma

They waited to hear your thinking on how to resolve it.

exchanges.text: Can we keep our army concentrated, keep a force guarding their gates against a sally from the fort while also bombarding them with our cannons until we have forced a breach? Do we have to totally surround a fort in order for the bombards to do their work?

Pietro Calabrese (the artillery expert) should speak first and most authoritatively on this. Then the veteran commanders can discuss the tactical implications.

Pietro Calabrese stepped forward immediately, his eyes lighting up. The Italian gunner had been waiting for someone to ask about his bombards properly.

"Your Majesty, yes! Absolutely yes. The bombards, they do not need full encirclement. In fact, better without it!"

He moved to the map excitedly, gesturing as he spoke:

"A proper siege with bombards—we choose one section of wall, maybe two if fortress is large. We position the guns here, here"—he pointed—"perhaps 300 yards from walls. Close enough to be accurate, far enough to be safe from their arrows and crossbows. We pound the same section of wall again and again. Ten shots per gun per day if we are careful. Fifty shots total across five guns. In a week, maybe ten days—breach."

Don García Fernández grasped the implication immediately:

"So we don't need siege lines around the entire fortress. We just need to control the ground where the bombards sit and prevent sallies from the gates. The rest of the army stays concentrated, mobile, ready to face the Sultan's field army if it comes."

Pedro González studied the concept:

"Your Majesty's thinking is sound. We position the bombards on one side of the fortress—whichever side offers best ground and firing positions. We deploy perhaps 5,000 troops to guard the guns and prevent sallies. The remaining 18,000 stay concentrated in fighting formation, ready for field battle. When the Sultan arrives with his relief army, we're not scattered around the fortress—we're concentrated and ready to meet him."

Don Rodrigo de Narváez considered the tactical details:

"The garrison can't sally effectively against 5,000 troops, especially with the main army nearby. And they can't stop the bombardment—no fortress has counter-battery capability against our guns. They'd have to just sit inside and endure while we pound their walls. Meanwhile, if the Sultan's field army approaches, we're not caught divided. We're ready for battle."

Infante Enrique nodded approvingly:

"This is much better. We maintain offensive pressure on the fortress without surrendering mobility. And critically, Your Majesty—we're not trying to starve them out, which takes months. We're battering down walls with gunpowder, which takes days. Speed is everything."

Pietro Calabrese continued enthusiastically:

"And Your Majesty, once we make breach—maybe after eight, ten days of bombardment—then we can assault. We don't need to surround fortress to assault a breach. We concentrate troops at the breach point, storm through with overwhelming numbers. The rest of fortress doesn't matter if we break through in one place."

Don Álvar Pérez de Guzmán raised a practical consideration:

"The garrison will try to repair the breach at night, Your Majesty. They'll pile rubble, build makeshift walls behind the breach. But with five bombards concentrating fire, we can break wall faster than they can repair it. And when we do assault through the breach, 5,000 troops is more than enough—probably overkill for most of these fortresses."

Don Juan de Luna saw the larger strategic picture:

"So we advance to Alcalá la Real with the entire army concentrated. We position the bombards, assign 5,000 men to guard them and conduct the bombardment. The remaining 18,000—the vast bulk of our strength—stays in fighting formation two or three miles behind the bombardment position. If the Sultan's army appears, we're ready. If not, we breach the walls in ten days and storm through with overwhelming force."

Don Sancho de Rojas added:

"And once we take the fortress, we garrison it with perhaps 500 men and move on to the next one. The army never divides, never becomes vulnerable to being struck piecemeal. We're always concentrated, always ready for field battle."

Pedro González summarized the tactical concept:

"Your Majesty has identified the solution. We use the bombards to break fortresses quickly without traditional encirclement. This keeps the army concentrated and mobile—ready to fight the Sultan's field army on favorable terms whenever he commits. We get the benefits of siege warfare—taking fortresses, securing our advance—without the vulnerability of divided forces."

He paused. "There's one risk: the Sultan might attack the bombardment position itself with his cavalry, try to capture or destroy the guns. (2) Command structure — Enrique commands siege works (5,000) as anvil; Garcia Fernandez First Battle (5,000); Padilla Second Battle (5,000, overall infantry); Narvaez Third Battle (5,000); Juan commands heavy cavalry (4,000) as hammer. We are building the fieldworks to protect them from cavalry raids. But what is a cavalry raid going to do when they breach the defence and reach the cannon? Swords do little against these bronce beasts. Killing the gunners is what is really vulnerable about them right? Or maybe light some gunpowder to blow them up? 
Remind me, Are the cannons themselves not prectically invulnerable?

1. Bronze/iron cannons in 1430s are extremely durable and heavy
2. Cavalry with swords can't damage the metal significantly
3. But they CAN:
   - Kill the gunners (the real vulnerability)
   - Spike the touchhole with a metal spike (makes gun unusable until cleared)
   - Destroy wooden gun carriages/platforms
   - Scatter or destroy ammunition
   - Blow up gunpowder stores
   - Kill/scatter the oxen needed to move the guns

The guns themselves are nearly indestructible to cavalry attack with swords. But making them USELESS is easy - kill the crews, spike the touchholes, burn the powder, destroy the carriages.

I should have Pedro or Pietro explain this clearly, since Juan is asking a tactical question.

Pietro Calabrese immediately responded to the question with professional authority:

"Your Majesty understands correctly! The guns themselves—" he slapped the side of one of the massive bronze bombards affectionately "—practically indestructible. Five thousand pounds of bronze. You hit with sword, you break sword, not gun. Even if Moorish cavalry overruns position, they cannot damage the metal. Too heavy to carry away—need the ox teams and many hours to move even one gun."

The Italian gunner's expression turned serious. "But Your Majesty sees the real vulnerability: my crews. Each gun needs six men to operate properly. Loader, rammer, powder man, aimer, two assistants. If cavalry kills my gunners—" he shrugged expressively "—the gun sits silent. Beautiful bronze sculpture, useless for battle."

Don Rodrigo de Narváez added tactical details:

"There's more, Your Majesty. Even if they can't damage the guns themselves, cavalry raiders could spike the touchholes—hammer an iron spike into the firing hole. Makes the gun unusable until we drill it out, which takes hours or days. They could destroy the wooden gun carriages and platforms—that's all wood, burns easily. They could scatter or smash the ammunition stones. And most critically, they could destroy the gunpowder stores."

Infante Enrique nodded:

"The powder is the real danger, Your Majesty. If raiders reach the magazines and set fire to the barrels..." He made an explosive gesture with his hands. "Not only do we lose all our powder, but the explosion could kill dozens of our own men and possibly damage the gun carriages or platforms. That's why powder must be stored carefully and guarded obsessively."

Pietro Calabrese continued:

"Also, Your Majesty, they kill or scatter the oxen. Each gun needs eight oxen to move. Those animals are valuable, expensive, hard to replace. Kill the oxen teams, and the guns are stuck where they sit. Cannot advance, cannot retreat. Bronze is indestructible, yes, but immobile gun is useless gun if we must leave the position."

Don García Fernández synthesized this into tactical terms:

"So Your Majesty, the fieldworks aren't protecting the metal of the guns—you're right, that's nearly indestructible. The fieldworks protect the crews, the powder, the ammunition, the carriages, the oxen. Everything around the gun that makes it actually function. A cavalry raid that breaks through could render all five bombards useless in minutes without scratching the bronze."

Don Álvar Pérez de Guzmán added:

"And Your Majesty, there's psychological effect. If Moorish cavalry captures or destroys our artillery, even temporarily, it's enormous blow to morale. The bombards are symbols of our technical superiority, our ability to break walls. Losing them—or even having them spiked and silenced—could shake the army's confidence."

Pedro González concluded:

"So the fieldworks serve multiple purposes, Your Majesty. They protect the vulnerable elements around the guns—crews, powder, supplies, animals. They create a perimeter that prevents raiders from getting close enough to spike touchholes or set fires. And they give our infantry defensive positions to repel attacks without having to fight in the open."

The Master paused. "But Your Majesty's question cuts to the key issue: how elaborate do these fieldworks need to be? Basic earthworks and ditches might suffice to stop a cavalry raid—horsemen can't easily cross ditches or charge up earthen ramparts. We don't necessarily need the elaborate Roman fortifications we originally envisioned if the primary threat is cavalry trying to silence the guns."

Don Rodrigo de Narváez considered this:

"A ditch six feet deep and eight feet wide, with the excavated earth piled as a rampart behind it—that stops cavalry cold. They can't jump it, can't ride up the rampart. Add sharpened stakes in the ditch and along the rampart, and it's nearly impenetrable to mounted troops. Infantry can defend such a position easily."

Don Juan de Luna added from his recent reconnaissance experience:

"And Your Majesty, the Sultan's cavalry—even the excellent Moroccan horsemen—aren't going to throw themselves suicidally at defended earthworks just to spike some cannons. Cavalry are valuable, hard to replace. They'll probe for weaknesses, maybe harass, but a determined assault on prepared positions? That's not how they fight. They want mobility and advantage, not grinding assaults."

The commanders waited to see how this practical assessment of artillery vulnerability affected your thinking about the fortifications and the approaching Sultan's army.

"We were planning to position them tomorrow morning, Your Majesty, once the fieldworks were further along. But with the Sultan arriving in two days..." He left the implication hanging.

I want to see if we can bait the sultan into attacking while we are setting up. Deploy one gun now and keep the rest safe in reserve and out of sight. The gun that is being deployed should start shooting as soon as possible, but we limit the amount of ammunition and gunpowder we send into the siege camp. We light some fires in the camp to harden the spikes but we let this also create smoke. 3. Limit ammo/powder near the gun (reduce loss if overrun)

This is actually quite clever - it's a deliberate trap. Make it look like they're caught building, sultan commits to attack thinking he has advantage, then Juan reveals his full strength.

The commanders would need to assess this. Some would see the cleverness, some might worry about risks. Let me have 2-3 respond naturally.

Pedro González would likely see the strategic merit immediately. Maybe one cavalry commander comments on the feigned retreat aspect. Pietro might worry about his gun but understand the tactical purpose.

I need to keep responses shorter and more natural - not everyone chiming in.

Pedro González listened carefully, then a slow smile spread across his face:

"Your Majesty... that's cunning. Very cunning. We make it look like we've been caught unprepared—one gun deployed prematurely, hasty construction, thin defenses. The Sultan sees what he hoped to see: us vulnerable, scrambling. He commits to attack. Then we reveal the full army and force the field battle on our terms."

Don García Fernández grinned:

"And the troops we stage to 'flee'—that sells it completely. Sultan's cavalry sees Castilians running, thinks they've broken our advance guard, charges forward thinking they have momentum. By the time they realize the trap, his whole army is committed and our twenty-three thousand are deploying in good order."

Pietro Calabrese looked conflicted, protective of his guns:

"Your Majesty risks one of my bombards if they overrun the position. But..." he sighed heavily, "...if it draws him into attacking, if it wins the battle—one gun is acceptable loss. And you are right, with limited powder and ammunition nearby, even if they capture the position, they cannot do much damage. The gun itself survives, we retake it after battle."

Pedro González was already thinking through the tactical details:

"The ditches and basic earthworks—yes, that's perfect. Just enough to give our five thousand infantry a defensive advantage against his initial attack, not so elaborate it looks like we're fully prepared. And the smoke from the fires will obscure exactly how many troops we have in the siege camp versus in reserve."

He paused, studying you. "Your Majesty, this requires discipline. The five thousand at the siege position must hold when the Sultan attacks—at least initially, to make it look real. Some might actually panic when they see seventeen thousand Moors coming at them. And timing the main army's deployment is critical—too early and we reveal the trap, too late and the five thousand get overrun for real."

Pietro, we are not sacrificing the gun needlessly. As soon as we see that battle is about to start, your gunners are to retreat to the rear and join the other guns. They are the most valuable part of the cannon. They carry any gunpowder reserve back with them. It is important though that the sultan knows that there is artillery in the camp, so fire a few shots with the Moors in sight. Bring the oxen in after deployment as well.


Now, this council is going to decide who will man the siege works. We need our most determined troops in that position to anchor the sultan's army. I propose we deploy the crusaders there. What other forces should we deploy there?

No, we do not deploy bad troops because we expect them to flee. Absolutely not. "Your Majesty identifies the exact danger. Their seven thousand cavalry—especially those Moroccan professionals—are their best weapon. Infante Enrique added grimly:

"I've seen it happen. Infantry wins the initial clash, starts chasing routing enemies, formations dissolve as men seek plunder and glory. Then enemy cavalry appears from the flanks—suddenly your victorious infantry are scattered individuals being ridden down. Turns victory into slaughter."

Their strength is clearly in their superiour and mobile cavalry. How can one defeat a force that can always retreat and choose when it offers battle? Is their reliance on infantry support a weakness if we can destroy the infantry?

- If Sultan loses his infantry, his cavalry becomes raiders not an army
